Award.AwardTitle: Earthquake nucleation on faults with rate- and state-dependent friction: a dynamical system's approach to instability
Award.AbstractNarration:
An outstanding problem in earthquake science is how fault slip transitions from slow creep or a nearly locked state to an earthquake-generating dynamic rupture of the fault. Fundamental questions are how an evolving fault friction allows for and determines the development of a slip instability that ultimately nucleates dynamic rupture; how conditions on the fault affect that development; and what are the consequences for the seismic cycle and the discernment of earthquakes at their earliest stages. There is societal and scientific interest in understanding how earthquakes start. Without an understanding of how dynamic fault rupture is initiated, it is unlikely we will reliably understand the origin of the earliest seismic signals that are crucial for early warning systems.

Through recent work, we have developed a transformative understanding of slip instability formation on interfaces of elastic bodies whose friction follows the prevalent slip rate- and state- dependence indicated by laboratory friction experiments at low, interseismic slip rates. Treating a slipping fault as a nonlinear dynamical system, we have found the manner by which earthquake-nucleating slip instabilities develop on such interfaces. In the dynamical system context, the development corresponds to fixed-point attraction. Our novel approach has opened up new avenues to address, in rigorous detail, several of the fundamental issues concerning nucleation: whether preferential nucleation sites can exist and, if identified, how they may be expressed in the seismic cycle and what they may imply about the distribution of the local intensity of rate-weakening or rate-strengthening behavior; whether the nucleation process may be a chaotic one, such that small changes in initial conditions at the onset of a slip instability may result in large differences in the moments immediately preceding dynamic rupture; and how spatial variations of fault properties and conditions (such as fault gouge composition and thickness, ambient temperatures and pore fluid pressures) control nucleation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Earthquakes emerge in a seemingly spontaneous fashion due to the sudden nucleation and rapid propagation of a rupture along a fault. In this project we sought a theoretical underpinning for a mechanism mediating the transition from a locked or slowly slipping fault to the rapid slip that generates an earthquake. We considered laboratory-constrained descriptions of how fault strength depends on instantaneous sliding rate of a fault interface, as well as its history, or state. We showed that non-linear, slip rate- and state-dependent fault frictional strength—when coupled with quasi-static, linear-elastic deformation of the fault host rock—gives rise to the existence solutions in which fault slip rate diverges within finite time. These solutions provide a mechanism to nucleate an earthquake-generating dynamic rupture of a fault, as the rapid and localized acceleration of fault slip implied by these solutions is ultimately limited by the inertia of the host rock.

Furthermore, we found that these solutions, characterized by a blow-up of slip rate, can be considered as fixed points of a dynamical system and, moreover, we found that these fixed points can lose stability as a problem parameter increases: i.e., an increase in the relative contribution to frictional strength of so-called direct and evolution effects. This loss of stability illustrates that current conceptions of fault frictional strength can present a dichotomy in the rapid acceleration preceding an earthquake. In one regime, in which solutions for diverging slip rate are stable, a nucleation phase is expected to be self-similar and progress in a manner that is largely independent of the preceding state of the fault. In the other regime, in which the instability solutions are themselves unstable, the acceleration of fault slip—including the size of the fault region that unstably accelerates—is highly sensitive to the fault conditions prior to acceleration and hence likely varies from event to event.

The dynamical systems analysis applied here reduces the complexity of model fault systems and provides a means to address a number of outstanding questions. Another prominent focus and result of the project has been the determination of how heterogeneity in fault frictional properties influences earthquake nucleation. Specifically, we demonstrated that such heterogeneity can lead to preferential sites of earthquake nucleation, the location of which are determined a priori by the property distributions. 

Sliding interfaces subject to frictional instability are found not only on faults within rocks, but also at the base of ice streams and the landsliding motion of hillslopes. In developing the results here on the emergence of unstable acceleration, we considered the potential range of scenarios—from the sliding of slabs of material near the Earth’s surface to the sliding along interfaces deep underground—and found that our results are quantitatively and qualitatively similar, independent of the sliding configuration.

The project provided for the support and training of a graduate student, who received training in a number of advanced numerical and analytical methods, as well as the interpretation of relevant laboratory and field observations.
